conclusion: To determine the maximum distance between Car A and Car B between the two instances when they are side by side, we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph provided.
Car A has a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 10 s to t = 30 s.
Car B accelerates uniformly from t = 0 s to t = 30 s.

premise: The position of a car can be found by calculating the area under the v-t graph.
conclusion: For Car A, from t = 0 s to t = 10 s, Car A is at rest (velocity = 0), so the distance covered is 0.

premise: Car A moves at a constant velocity of 40 m/s from t = 10 s to t = 30 s.
conclusion: Distance covered by Car A = 40 m/s × (30 s - 10 s) = 800 m.

premise: Car B accelerates uniformly from 0 to 40 m/s over 30 seconds.
conclusion: Distance covered by Car B = 1/2 × base × height = 1/2 × 30 × 40 = 600 m.

premise: At t = 30 s, both cars are side by side, meaning they have covered the same distance up to this point.
conclusion: We need to find another instance when they are side by side.

premise: Since Car A starts moving at t = 10 s, we check the distance covered by both cars at t = 10 s.
conclusion: Car A: 0 m (since it starts moving at t = 10 s). Car B: Distance covered = 1/2 × 10 × 40 = 200 m.

premise: The maximum distance occurs when the difference in their positions is greatest.
conclusion: From t = 10 s to t = 30 s, Car A moves 800 m. Car B moves from 200 m to 600 m, covering an additional 400 m.

premise: Car A moves 800 m and Car B moves an additional 400 m from 200 m.
conclusion: The difference in distance = 800 m - 400 m = 400 m.
